<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 232, 294]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 278, 907, 294]]<|/det|>
9709/63  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 303, 343, 319]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Probability & Statistics 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 303, 907, 320]]<|/det|>
October/November 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 329, 907, 345]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 357, 395, 373]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 418, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 435, 875, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 664, 216, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
It is known that the height \(H\), in metres, of trees of a certain kind has the distribution \(\mathrm{N}(12.5, 10.24)\). A scientist takes a random sample of 25 trees of this kind and finds the sample mean, \(\overline{H}\), of the heights.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 120, 665, 139]]<|/det|>
State the distribution of \(\overline{H}\), giving the values of any parameters.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 333, 146, 352]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 333, 332, 352]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{P}(12 < \overline{H} < 13)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 333, 920, 352]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
The number of enquiries received per day at a customer service desk has a Poisson distribution with mean 45.2. If more than 60 enquiries are received in a day, the customer service desk cannot deal with them all.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
Use a suitable approximating distribution to find the probability that, on a randomly chosen day, the customer service desk cannot deal with all the enquiries that are received. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
A random sample of 75 students at a large college was selected for a survey. 15 of these students said that they owned a car. From this result an approximate \(\alpha \%\) confidence interval for the proportion of all students at the college who own a car was calculated. The width of this interval was found to be 0.162.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 152, 556, 170]]<|/det|>
Calculate the value of \(\alpha\) correct to 2 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 152, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 618, 92]]<|/det|>
A random variable \(X\) has probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 98, 635, 141]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}\frac{1}{18} (9 - x^2) & 0\leqslant x\leqslant 3,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}. \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 160, 146, 178]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 160, 295, 178]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{P}(X < 1.2)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 160, 920, 178]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 560, 198, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 562, 248, 581]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{E}(X)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 562, 920, 581]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
The proportion of people having a particular medical condition is 1 in 100 000. A random sample of 2500 people is obtained. The number of people in the sample having the condition is denoted by \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 129, 196, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 128, 920, 163]]<|/det|>
State, with a justification, a suitable approximating distribution for \(X\), giving the values of any parameters. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 380, 193, 397]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 380, 655, 397]]<|/det|>
Use the approximating distribution to calculate \(\mathrm{P}(X > 0)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 380, 920, 397]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
The percentage of people having a different medical condition is thought to be \(30\%\). A researcher suspects that the true percentage is less than \(30\%\). In a medical trial a random sample of 28 people was selected and 4 people were found to have this condition.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
Use a binomial distribution to test the researcher's suspicion at the \(2\%\) significance level. [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 170, 920, 188]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(T\) denotes the time, in seconds, for \(100\mathrm{m}\) races run by Tania. \(T\) is normally distributed with mean \(\mu\) and variance \(\sigma^2\). A random sample of 40 races run by Tania gave the following results.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 125, 648, 144]]<|/det|>
\[n = 40\qquad \Sigma t = 560\qquad \Sigma t^2 = 7850\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 163, 146, 180]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 160, 492, 179]]<|/det|>
Calculate unbiased estimates of \(\mu\) and \(\sigma^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 163, 920, 180]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(S\) denotes the time, in seconds, for \(100 \mathrm{~m}\) races run by Suki. \(S\) has the independent distribution N(14.2, 0.3).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 148, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to part (a), find the probability that, in a randomly chosen \(100 \mathrm{~m}\) race, Suki's time will be at least 0.1 s more than Tania's time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
The masses, in grams, of apples from a certain farm have mean \(\mu\) and standard deviation 5.2. The farmer says that the value of \(\mu\) is 64.6. A quality control inspector claims that the value of \(\mu\) is actually less than 64.6. In order to test his claim he chooses a random sample of 100 apples from the farm.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 146, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 135, 599, 154]]<|/det|>
The mean mass of the 100 apples is found to be \(63.5 \mathrm{~g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 166, 541, 185]]<|/det|>
Carry out the test at the \(2.5\%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 166, 920, 185]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Later another test of the same hypotheses at the \(2.5\%\) significance level, with another random sample of 100 apples from the same farm, is carried out.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 818, 138]]<|/det|>
Given that the value of \(\mu\) is in fact 62.7, calculate the probability of a Type II error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 74, 569, 92]]<|/det|>
## Additional Page  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 104, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
If you use the following lined page to complete the answer(s) to any question(s), the question number(s) must be clearly shown.
